abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking Sector Reform Project for
            Iraq had an overall moderately satisfactory outcome, with
            the Bank's performance deemed to be satisfactory, while
            the borrower's performance was felt to be moderately
            satisfactory. The project indicators show encouraging
            improvements and progress. Significant lessons were learned
            during the implementation of the project in the following
            areas: 1) strong analytic underpinning and building on other
            operations; 2) consultations with stakeholders for building
            consensus; 3) effective cooperation with development
            practices for ensuring good coordination, and leveraging in
            pushing reforms; 4) strong and sustained partnership; 5)
            difficulties in finding international experts to travel to
            Baghdad because of the security situation; and 6) the
            importance of a combination of on-site and off-site missions
            for operations in conflict countries.

repnme.cdata!: Iraq - Emergency Banking Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Banking
            Sector Reform Project in Iraq is to strengthen the
            supervisory framework for financial intermediation and to
            build capacity of financial institutions to support
            implementation of first phase of the Iraq banking reform
            strategy specifically, the operation will focus on four main
            components: (i) institutional and operational restructuring
            of the two main state-owned commercial banks (Rasheed Bank
            and Rafidain Bank); (ii) financial restructuring of the two
            main state-owned commercial banks; (iii) strengthening of
            the regulatory and supervisory functions of Central Bank of
            Iraq (CBI); and (iv) project management, monitoring and
            evaluation. Overall, this operation will assist Iraq in
            implementing first phase of their program, covering the
            period from 2009 to 2010. It will thereby foster more
            efficient financial intermediation, resource mobilization
            and risk management, and, in the medium-term, it will permit
            an increase in private participation in the provision of
            financial services.
